awd_titl_txt: Adaptive High Order Low-Rank Tensor Methods for High-Dimensional Partial Differential Equations with Application to Kinetic Simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
Kinetic models find a wide range of applications in science and engineering. One celebrated example is the Vlasov-Maxwell system which plays a fundamental role in plasma physics. Among many existing challenges for deterministic kinetic simulations, the curse of dimensionality and the associated huge computational cost have been a key obstacle for realistic high-dimensional simulations. The project focuses on the development of a novel computational framework for kinetic simulations by integrating the emerging low-rank tensor decompositions with advanced high order discretization schemes. The framework can lead to a class of accurate and efficient algorithms that are resistant to the curse of dimensionality for solving challenging high-dimensional problems. This project will support one graduate student during each of the three years of the project. 

The main objective of the project is to develop a novel computational framework for simulating high-dimensional kinetic models with high order accuracy, numerical stability, and manageable cost. The algorithms incorporate the emerging tensor approach and advanced high order discretization schemes, aiming to accurately and efficiently extract the low-rank structure of the solution data with significantly reduced complexity and potentially break the curse of dimensionality. Another project focus is to develop a novel low-rank tensor approach that can mitigate possible severe rank increase for transport-dominated simulations, which is known as a major limitation for the existing low-rank tensor methods. The key component in the algorithm design is to consider the underlying flow map system. Several computational and theoretical aspects of the proposed algorithms will be investigated, including structure preservation, complexity, stability and accuracy analysis, application to the rotating Vlasov model, and beyond. Through this research, both numerical and analytical techniques for solving challenging high-dimensional problems will be advanced.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project develops efficient low-rank tensor methods for solving nonlinear, multi-scale, high-dimensional partial differential equations (PDEs) that arise in fluid dynamics, plasma physics, astronomy, and other scientific and engineering disciplines. These methods tackle longstanding challenges such as the curse of dimensionality, nonlinearity, preservation of inherent structures, and multi-scale features. By leveraging and advancing tensor decomposition techniques, the proposed methods significantly reduce the computational complexity of simulating high-dimensional PDEs, achieving substantial computational savings. Furthermore, these methods are designed to ensure high accuracy while preserving critical inherent structures, thereby guaranteeing efficiency, reliability, and robustness in simulations.

These methods have been successfully applied to plasma simulations. Effective plasma prediction and control are crucial for addressing the climate crisis, achieving energy independence, and tackling other critical challenges facing modern society. The underlying model for describing plasmas is the Vlasov transport equation, defined in a six-dimensional phase space and nonlinearly coupled with Maxwell’s equations of electromagnetism. Classical high-fidelity simulations of the Vlasov model for plasmas are computationally prohibitive, even on modern supercomputers. The proposed methods effectively explore the underlying low-rank structure of the Vlasov model as well as the solution by leveraging advanced tensor decompositions, achieving significant data compression and alleviating the curse of dimensionality. Moreover, the proposed methods achieve the highly desired local conservation property for plasma simulation, which is critical for predicting shock locations, ensuring long-term accuracy and stability, and avoiding unphysical artifacts such as plasma self-heating or cooling. Furthermore, the method is extended to simulate multi-scale linear kinetic transport equations, which are critical to understanding physical processes in diverse fields such as nuclear engineering, astrophysics, and computational medicine. In addition to mitigating the curse of dimensionality, the method achieves high order accuracy while preserving the correct asymptotic limit.
